Home buyers outpace sellers in Boston

The number of homes for sale has dropped, increasing competition and pushing up long-depressed prices, a trend that could speed the market’s recovery.
Opinion | Adrian Walker

Scott Brown vs. 'the welfare vote'

For Senator Brown, registering people on welfare to vote is a waste of money, apparently, and a dirty trick. Voting is for the people who will vote for you.

Goddard House nursing home
a casualty of funding, times

The rise of assisted-living facilities and a shift to care allowing elders to remain at home have caused a decline in the number of facilities.
Opinion | Bob Ryan

Spain regroups for rematch with US

Spain struggled but won the games that counted. Now they will play the Americans Sunday in a rematch of the 2008 Olympic title game.
The Roads to Summer

Cape Cod flea market still thriving

Four mornings each week, the Wellfleet Drive-in devotes nearly a square mile of parking lot to one of the area’s largest and most legendary flea markets.
Opinion | LAWRENCE HARMON

Does anthrax risk end at city limits?

In case of an anthrax attack, most Boston residents could expect next-day delivery of antibiotics. But those living just outside the city limits will require contingency plans.

Politics

The story behind Romney's IRA

Mitt Romney has used an individual retirement account to shield at least $20 million and as much as $100 million from initial taxes. Congress established the accounts to help average Americans save for retirement.
